review_title: Toxic work environment and too hierarchical
pros: You will meet some really passionate people who believe in the cause below senior management who are absolutely amazing.
cons:
The organisation is very top-down, hierarchical. Senior management does not care about their staff, listen to their opinions, trust that they hired them to do their job and treat them without the respect or dignity they deserve. 

The board and CEO run the whole organisation and lead the charge in an extremely backward view of conservation. Many of the people the hire include CEO and COO or consultants know nothing about conservation or sustainability and yet boss everyone around like they are running a dictatorship. They are losing valuable, amazing and talented people and they don't care as the treat their jobs like it's a retirement job and it's the last leg of their career. Whereas the people who actually care and want to make real change are being dumbed down, pushed aside and expected to do as asked with no ability to think outside the box what so ever. Forget about career progression unless you are senior management, no promotions at all. 

The extreme micro-management and approval processes makes a non-profit that is supposed to lead the change absolutely redundant and useless. I have completely lost faith in the integrity and responsibility of the organisation to make systemic change and do its job for the right cause.

To all of us the heads n ceo have no heart for conservation and no respect for people. Who can blame them.. it is a cushy job and they have to guard it. This ngo is run by a bunch of fame hungry individuals with delicate egos and guess what.... the management ridicules you publicly in meetings and brown noses the mysterious board. every one here is just biding time and looking to jump ship at the next chance but this is maybe a good resting ground using donor money.. disappointing.. DO. NOT. JOIN.

review_title: Hierarchical, toxic, power hungry and government serving agenda
pros: The junior level staff is passionate, dedicated and quite frankly, are much more productive than the senior level management.
cons:
Senior management has no conservation background. In fact, they barely have any NGO background. The rather mysterious board with connections to the government seems to be running the show to please the government and pat them on their back rather than reflect on the real environmental issues of our time. 

What is even worse is that anyone in an implementer position is paid terribly, with little or no chance of career development and growth. In contrast, while nobody really knows where donor money truly goes, senior management get paid expat level salaries and seem to be easily promoted, even though they do no work.

If you're looking to join at a junior level because you are passionate about the cause, please look elsewhere. This is a sweatshop that will dry you out to fill senior management pockets with donor money and keep the government happy.

review_title: This place never fails to disappoint
pros: Junior staff can be quite passionate and enthusiastic!
cons:
- The pay is a joke. You can expect to hear how the management is "reviewing the salary structure", it's a lie. I have heard this for over a year and the only salary bumps you will see happening are your friends’ who do not work in WWF. There is literally ZERO adjustment to your salary unless you get promoted, and even then the pay raise is ridiculously low. What this means is that if you factor in inflation, your purchasing power is literally decreasing year by year. Meanwhile, whatever money the organisation does have goes into hiring consultants who are paid to do the jobs of the management themselves. I get that you don’t enter an NGO for money, but at the very least, shouldn’t a company provide fair wages? What makes this fact even harder to swallow is that we actively advocate for businesses to pay their employees fairly as required by sustainable certifications, but we fail to hold ourselves to the same standards. After seeing this happening for so long, I have decided to stop all my donations to this place. I would rather burn this money than continue giving it away to this bunch of self-serving people.

- Big egos and a complete lack of understanding towards conservation amongst the management. The former could be addressed if the people in question are willing to learn but unfortunately the majority choose to remain wilfully ignorant or outright refuse to bother. The situation is exacerbated when the management attempts to run this organisation like a private business (e.g. a bank) or like an army. Some of the C-suite level/directors are unable to take no for an answer and will retaliate to make your life utterly miserable. The rest are too scared to stand up for what's right and will simply watch as this happens. Pretty ironic considering how this company claims that its values include courage and integrity. The management fails to see that conservation includes more than protection of habitats, it includes educating the public, holding businesses and governments accountable for their actions. Granted that Singapore’s politics are harder to influence; this does not mean impossible. However, since the board and even some members of the management have connections with the politicians, they are leery of anything that could be seen as “criticism”. So if you are looking to change Sg in this manner, look elsewhere. There are local NGOs who do a better job than this place.

- Lack of communication, transparency and trust. This organisation has a nasty habit of springing bad news and key developments/changes (e.g. the changing of our 13th month pay) last minute, usually in the late evening or at night on a Friday. Announcements are made with no proper brief, no proper FAQs and employees are just supposed to roll with it. If this is a tactic to evade potential backlash and give employees time to adapt during the weekend, I would advise you to fire your HR team or whoever that gave you this bright idea. All this does is ruin your employees’ rest as they unnecessarily panic. We often do not know what goes on amongst the management and what are their plans (to be fair, they probably have no idea what they are doing either) – we are just supposed to execute. Which would be fine, but often times the decisions made are irrational and a waste of donor money. By the way, town halls are not an answer – nobody wants to sit through 3 hours long town halls. 

- Here’s a special shout out to the HR team: Nobody trusts you. Nobody. Let’s not even talk about protecting the staff. Let’s just talk about how you fail even at the core tenets of your jobs. Number 1: hiring the right person for the role. More often than not, scummy people are hired (even to your own team) and they can’t even do their jobs right. At one point, we even had a HR head that does not know or bother to learn our local labour laws. Granted that he is now gone, but the fact that he was ever hired proves how incompetent this team, and by large, the management team, is. Number 2: career progression. The lack of progression amongst the junior staff is extremely concerning. Pair this up with the phenomenon where you see incidences of expats > locals being promoted to senior/managerial positions; you get a ticking time bomb. Why are your employees constantly forced to jump through so many hoops to be promoted? If they are already doing above and beyond what their JD is, shouldn’t this be cause for promotion?? Why the over emphasis on the number of years of work exp/services? Why are you not evaluating based on competency and achievements? 3: Employee retention. In the first quarter of the year, the number of people leaving this organisation is in the double digits and this does not seem like it will end. Isn’t this high time to take a good hard look at yourself and admit where you are screwing up? It’s not hard, you can dig up the recent exit interviews.

- Double standards. New employees are expected to have the necessary skills/knowledge to do their jobs when they are hired. Afterwards, they have a probation period to evaluate and confirm that they know how to do their jobs. I don’t think this requirement is being imposed on our management. We have seen two CEOs now that do not know or understand conservation work despite the fact that they have been in position for about a YEAR. We have seen directors that frankly speaking, do not know what conservation is as well. While we do not expect them to possess deep technical knowledge, it is disturbing that they don’t even understand the bigger picture or what their team is doing. BY THE WAY, your staff knows when you are fluffing. We say nothing because we don’t want to get fired. Just know that is incredibly frustrating because it makes us wonder – why on earth are you paid at this level when you can’t deliver? Educate yourself and stop wasting our time and the organisation’s money. 

I can go on and on but I am exhausted. We all are, which is why we are all leaving one by one. Good luck to all who enter, I do not wish this place on my worst enemy.

review_title: Best culture I've ever worked in
job_title: Works In Marketing and Communications in Washington, DC
pros: I worked for a long time as a consultant, lots of clients, lots of different companies, lots of personalties, lots of corporate climbing, etc. And eventually turned around one day and decided I wanted a mission I could care about, and a place that was culturally great. Those became my criteria, and WWF has been everything I've wanted. This place is filled with smart and passionate people, and I can go home every night feeling like I'm doing my part to help the world, which overrides much of the daily issues anyone faces in any job. The benefits are outstanding, there is great listening from most quarters of the organization, and the work means something.
cons: It is a large organization, as such, there is bureaucracy, and a big ship moves slower than a small one. However, positive internal change does happen, and I believe the Senior Management Team wants this to be a great place, and works towards making that happen—it is the best organization I've ever worked for.

pros: The pros are the people you'll work with, the level of access and impact that the organisation's reputation can provide and those occasional moments when the machine pulls together to move in the right direction and it feels like you're making a difference and having an impact. WWF attracts a mix of experts, and capable professionals from the private and public sector and has a wealth of institutional knowledge and a track record that can open doors to the people and businesses that matter. If this is the sort of thing you see as essential to affecting change then it may be the place for you.
cons: The Executive Group of the organisation are at the same distant and navel gazing and micromanaging and perpetually leaning in to the work of specialists. This can be both stifling and demotivating to those actually trying to deliver the work of the organisation. This, allied with frequent strategic refreshes make for an organisation that feels perpetually in transition. Cynicism can take root easily and that's not a good attitude for a mission driven organisation to be founded on.

Compensation isn't transparent. They'll send you a little excel sheet denoting how much you can expect to make over a few years with the company, but raises are never in line with what the sheet says. Company will not meet with you face to face to negotiate salaries/promotions. Will tell you they'll 'have to get back to you' and then a couple weeks later you'll get sent a new paycheck with a 2% cost of living adjustment and nothing else said about it. This place needs a union - but then again every place does.

review_title: In WWF, you are on your own; It is the wild west. dont expect great human experience.
pros:
- Big network
- Big name on your CV
- Access to many learning opportunities 
- Easily recognized by ordinary people, when they ask: where do you work
- Travels
cons:
- Panda is so giant to respect its team. Don't expect much. 
- Very weak human capital management. 
- If you don't want your hair to go grey in a matter of 2-3 years, don't go there. 
- Complicated unnecessary internal politics, twisting everything. 
- You will end up with no considerable positive result for conservation and you will start questioning yourself about it. 
- Every now and then the Global office come up with a new game of institutional rearrangement which wastes everyone's time. 
- If you don't belong to a gang inside the Org, you are a poor sheep in the middle of the wolfland. 
- If you are a conservationist, your major enemy will be the support team (HR, finance, Communication) sitting in their well-equipped offices and making it hard for you to the real job. 
- What will make you burn from inside is this: they don't care about you!

pros: Great repository of information for those who care about conservation. State offices and field researchers largely pleasant to interact with
cons:
Awful work environment. No true leadership wherever you look. Directors will play favourites or compete with each other to the point of harassing a perceived competitor's team member. Few managers are even megalomaniacal
Needlessly bureaucratic- they even keep a name register for the coffee machine.

review_title: Zero upward mobility and abuse of support staff
pros: Being off every other Friday nothing else
cons: As an assistant, you will be locked down in that position and be given every excuse possible on why you won’t be promoted no matter how hard you work / how much new responsibilities you take on. Whatever department you land in will abuse the support they get from you. Having you do things that nears wiping their behinds for them, literally. No accountability from upper management. They are in a clique, very gang like mentality. Upper management and managers wastes hundreds of thousands of dollars every year on frivolous business trips overseas. They take trips then turn them into personal vacation excursions. It’s a shame how they use animals/environment to waste the public’s and government’s dollars/euros. The Buzzfeed report is true!!! WWF is using a phony internal review to sweep the truth under the rug.

cons: Appalling management style from most senior leaders, endless pointless meetings, no real interest in conservation from the top. I typically spent five hours a day eating cake and chocolates in meetings, one hour a day having 'catch ups' with my completely inept manager, and a couple of hours doing actual work. There was an absurd focus on raising the profile of the CEO, rather than talking seriously about the issues facing our planet. If you are placid yes-person, apply for a job here right away. If you have spirit and brains, try a smaller and more focused organisation.

pros: Good experience working with the team

pros: Changing the ending one step at a time

pros: Good people, great culture, flexible
cons: Can't think of anything negative about working here.

pros: Brilliant professionals with world-class expertise in their fields; Very international organization; Green initiatives at the DC office; Intermural sports opportunities in DC like softball and soccer; Great DC office location and facilities; Many employees are talented and committed to what they do; Competitive salaries and benefits including every other Friday off
cons: Technically-strong people are often promoted to being managers and manage other people without having the skills or motivation to do so. This is especially difficult for young professionals when they run into managers who are uninterested in their development or growth. Many talented young people end up moving around the organization or eventually leaving in order to find managers who will support their growth without having to pay years of dues first. The CEO Carter Roberts sits on a pedestal and is completely unaware of the realities of most of his employees, i.e. those who are not on the executive or VP levels. The cost of living in DC is too high for most entry level professionals, those at WWF included. One needs to reach the Director level making $100K in order to be able to afford to live comfortably in the area especially with kids.

pros: great culture and work environment
cons: sometimes hard to balance tasks

job_title: Project Manager in Dar es Salaam, Dar es Salaam
pros: Housing allowance in addition to salary
cons: Poor pension scheme and limited disclosure of information before recruitment

review_title: Good for learning, but few opportunities to advance
pros:
People really walk the walk -- huge volume of hybrid cars in the parking lot, bottled water is frowned on, LEED building, tolerance and understanding is very important.
Casual dress code
As long as the work is done, it doesn't matter if you work from home, work a little bit, or just hang out.
Ample opportunities to travel on company dime
Peers are willing to help fellow peers (but not really help those below them)
if you make friends with the support staff, they can help you figure out who the nice and helpful people are, and who the egotistical jerks are.
cons:
Extremely slow pace -- unless they are going through one of the CONSTANT re-organizations, and then they are swift to eliminate
Senior management -- especially the CEO -- is very "star chamber." Not only are you not allowed to talk to the CEO unless you are a member of the elite, you are not allowed to talk to his assistant, either.
Board members are coddled and treated like royalty -- during a board meeting, staff was asked not to ride the elevators in case the board members needed them and they didn't want the board members to have to ride with the lowly staff members.
Not a lot of guidance or training, unless you are one of the few that "matter"

review_title: Great company, hard workers and all about conservation

pros: It was good stuff guys
cons: nothing negative here folks, it was good

pros: Can do and create what you like to do
cons: Too many small groups with company politics

pros: Good salary for a non-profit, decent benefits, early office closures on summer Fridays, many in conservation are doing/trying to do good work.
cons:
Staff can't even tell you what the mission is, or articulate what it is the organization does. If you're a comms professional, stay away! Your talents are wasted here. There is little opportunity for growth or learning.
Overall, the organization has no direction or long-term strategy. Things are literally falling apart due to management that doesn't care/doesn't have skills to fix things.
The CEO is super positive but seems totally oblivious to what actually goes on here, and how unhappy we all are, being driven into the ground by poor managers who are misusing donor dollars because they don't know what they're doing.
Compared to other non-profits, this is the messiest and worst I've ever worked for. Truly unfortunate for an organization with so much potential to make positive change.

pros: decent pay, nice first experience, trainings, bonus, travels

pros: Everyday I go to work with no pressure. Colleagues are very supportive and helpful.

review_title: Lack of diversity in management (Executive and Board) is appalling
pros: mission, great staff, well resourced, financially stable
cons: Executive and Board in the US are all White (males).

pros: The longer I work at the WWF the more I feel its mission is absolute gold. In the UK office (Woking), people are here because they genuinely care and most are incredibly talented. Career progression has been great from my experience, and support, training and development opportunities are there if you need them. Colleagues are an absolutely great bunch, in my experience. I love this place. Even if I eventually leave to try something different for a while, I expect I'll be back again.
cons: Different people have very different experiences of this place. It's been wonderful for me, but some have experienced bullying, some have terrible work-life balance and some feel they don't have a chance to progress. Like many charities, restructuring happens a lot with little benefit and significant ill effects on people's motivation and morale. The decision-making progress is often ridiculous with far too many layers of 'sign-off' and lack of trust in mid-level and junior members of staff. Direction and focus, certainly at the moment, are lacking.

review_title: Wonderful org ull of passionate people
pros: The people, are wonderful. There are wonderful benefits including every other friday off
cons: Upward mobility is difficult. Many people leave and return to move up

pros: Best place to learn on ground level but as an internship.
cons: lot of relocating and field work

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Washington, DC
pros: The people - good people, good mission. It's literally "save the world" kind of work, which makes it really gratifying to work at this organization and want to promote its cause. Lots of exposure to international cultures too - high ethnic diversity of employees and many different languages floating around this office at any given time. Wonderful colleagues and a great network of assistants to help new hires. GREAT benefits.
cons:
People do tend to get married to their jobs here - lots of long hours, but at least you're in good company! New hires - careful to keep up with the work/home balance, because international organizations have around the world, 24/7 demands.

The job review evaluation process (midyear reviews and final reviews) can be painful.  Often times its building politics based (there are some egos here - but hey, it's DC), or because of your relationship with your supervisor (a good review definitely depends on it). There's no opportunity for a rebuttal of a poor review for your end of year review - once your supervisor has the final word, that's it with HR.

pros: Good place to work, amazing, hardworking staff and an incredible office
cons: Difficult to get promoted internally.

pros: strong leadership with a common goal.
cons: the vast network is hard to navigate if you only work on national issues.

review_title: How its like to work with WWF

cons: If you dont deliver you go

review_title: Not bad depending on the department you're in
pros: People really care about the work they do here

pros: Recognizable brand, good fundraising, nice merchandising

review_title: Fun, social place where you'll be proud of your work
job_title: Project Manager in College Park, MD
pros:
--EVERY OTHER FRIDAY OFF!!!  Yes, throughout the year
--Lots of fun people of all ages.
--Fantastic organization that actually does good in the world.  They are truthful about where they spend their money!  It goes to good programs.
--While a hike from Dupont Metro or Foggy Bottom (15 mins each), nice location just past edge of G'town, close to West End and Dupont
--Managers can recommend  you to monthly & yearly recognition programs
--Lots of brown bag info lunches; great for those actually interested in animals, environment, etc!
--Free gym in building
--Parking garage
cons:
--People stay there, so it can be tough to move up.  New positions are rarely created.
--As above, 15 minute walk from Metros
--Every other year it seems offices move around.  So you may have an office one year then get stuck in a cube.

review_title: More Science! More leaders with science background and experience.
pros: The cause, the mission, the purpose - live in harmony with nature. Working with some very intelligent and passionate people.
cons: WWF seems to be more about marketing than science. It is understandable that advocacy is part in parcel with protecting nature, but when it's conducted by marketing and communications people instead of scientists and environmentalists, then the policy lacks integrity. I also am surprised how many people on staff don't actually engage in outdoor activities and adventures or practice what they preach about reduced consumption of meat, their choice of transportation, waste, and recycling.  Surprised to see so much leadership void of an environmental background. There are several events that leadership teams attend, they just happen to be dinners and black-tie events, not, conservation events.  Seems they may enjoy bright lights more than sunlight.

pros: cannot think of any pros
cons: the management making it worse

review_title: WWF has harmed my career prospects
pros: Some passionate, talented people working towards a great cause. Great offices, good employee benefits, fun, friendly and social place to work.
cons: Very poor management, zero accountability, lack of communication about pretty much everything, no career progression whatsoever, lots of politics -  favouritism in the workplace for promoting colleagues, always looking for external candidates and not prepared to develop loyal employees who have worked there longer, dangerous imbalance of young females  in smaller teams leading to bullying, lack of respect for more experienced colleagues, insubordination, loss of identity in new structure where communications is being funded at the expense of conservation science. Examples of colleagues suffering from stress due to bullying.

job_title: Online Marketing Associate Specialist in Washington, DC
pros:
Some of the best reasons to work at World Wildlife Fund:
- Panda Fridays (You get every other Friday off)
- There are many Professional Development opportunities
- There are great opportunities to collaborate across departments
- Supportive colleagues
cons:
Some of the worst reasons to work at World Wildlife Fund:
- If you are a diverse candidate, I will warn you that WWF is not the best environment for inclusivity or equity. I have seen an experienced, People of Color being gaslit by leadership, scared into not reporting their grievances to HR, criticized and punished for minor mistakes in comparison to their white counterparts, and voices of People of Color completely ignored when it comes to contributing to the wonderful work WWF does. During my time there 4 Women of Color left in less than one year due to the manipulation and covert racism experienced in that space.

pros: Work life balance is fantastic with flexible hours, office is closed over Christmas holiday, a healthy chunk of vacation time (at least more than my last job), summer hours, and an awesome casual dress code (we can wear flip flops and shorts). The team that I work for and my boss are very open and supportive. I also get to travel across Canada and work with partners and communities.
cons:
There's no diversity at the senior level and their biases are very obvious. There's a revolving CEO door. The new CEO is out of her depth. She's more about being chipper and bubbly and getting into the weeds than working at a CEO of an international environmental organization level. By the way, the chippy and bubbly nature is fake.

Management acts like a bunch of servers at a restaurant who don't know what they're doing and keep crashing into each other unceremoniously while serving a table in an otherwise empty restaurant.

review_title: WWF-UK don't even think about it!
pros: Meeting really inspiring conservationists from around the network. They are the ones on the frontline doing the real work and when you listen to their talks,  for a moment, you get to feel like you're making a difference
cons: New chief exec has absolutely no clue - or care for conservation. She doesn't trust any staff member who's been there for over 2 years.  So anyone who's worked their butt off for the cause for years is now being actively ignored. She's surrounded herself by a new exec group - not one of them has a conservation background. Its so hierarchial now you're unable to voice an opinion to anyone higher than your direct line manager.  EG seem to have forgotten that their staff are real people with lives and feelings and just treat them like commodities. If you’re thinking of working for WWF-UK then leave it a couple of years until the current chief exec has moved on.

review_title: Great teams with bad mid-level management
pros: WWF is a huge NGO with reach and influence. There is always a lot to do and people to meet.  Everyone is passionate about their work.
cons: The biggest problem is the toxic mid-level management, like director and senior director level.  Senior management and higher are working as best as they can on a lot of things.  But it's really rare that directors get promoted to VP level, which creates a toxicity down the chain.  It's very hierarchical in that way.  Senior directors can get apathetic, squat in their positions, and not have their team's professional development in mind.

pros:
- The office is laid back
- Nice location
- Great colleagues
- Great mission
cons:
-  If you have expertise other than in conservation don't waste your time here you'll be treated like garbage, conservation is always right and everyone else is wrong
- Some middle managers are weak and incompetent and they throw employees under the bus, they even pass off employee ideas as their own to hide their incompetence
- Some senior managers throw temper tantrums
- Senior leadership only cares about politicking 
- Staff at lower levels expected to do some of the tasks of managers and directors 
- Employment contract states that you don't get common law severance if you get let go. 2 weeks and you are on EI
- There is no parental leave top-up
- There is dwindling hope in the CEO making the workplace culture better, she says she's anti-bullying but there is bullying/microaggression/incivility happening right under her nose

pros:
Your co-workers will be very intelligent and accomplished, but some can be a bit snobby/hard to know.  There are also some great people though!  You feel like you're part of a higher cause.

The lunch brown bags are very interesting and help you know some of the great programs you are supporting.  The office is gorgeous, great location in DC, and very neatly decorated with animals etc. Plus it's a green building.
cons: There can be a lot of politics where those who suck up get ahead first.  It's pretty difficult to change departments.

review_title: strong but long underperforming organization just nose-dived, now adrift
pros: WWF has flexible work hours.  Employees are generally smart & hardworking colleagues.  It is in a good location and and has strong brand recognition.
cons: WWF is in bumbling through a massive reorganization and severe layoffs, leaving the organization in self-induced chaos.   Staff morale is abysmal. High-performing colleagues who asked difficult questions were almost universally laid off.  Many staff who were initially fired have now been invited back, a symptom of deeper flaws within the reorganization process.  (Most are declining the 'opportunity' to continue with the organization.)  Layoffs preceded strategic planning, so remaining employees are now charged with developing projects and programs without key personnel.  Workloads for remaining employees are ridiculous, sometimes dumping 2 and even 3 full-time positions onto a single individual.  And now the architects of the reorg are being fired, in a last-ditch effort to salvage things (or perhaps find a scapegoat).

review_title: WWF CANADA - How can you convince people to care about the planet when you don't even care about your own employees?
pros:
Summers are slow so you can get work done
Scientists are great people
cons:
-Sometimes you are need to lie about facts and numbers to make directors look good
-People on the top are true bullies, they use their power to make their ideas happen
-It's run like a franchise on maintenance mode, using international's brand to get money from donors mostly to pay directors and VP salaries
-Board of directors are the ones making the decisions, it's mostly people connected to corporations with their own interests such as Telus, Loblaw, Coke, RBC, HP
-No career growth (even when your performance review is amazing). You will never be given the opportunity to do something you don't know, they will hire a company or someone external to do it
-Low salary
-Can't achieve anything, just blablabla and a lot of "strategic planning"
-Made a partnership with Canada Goose even when everyone was against it

pros:
Worked at WWF-Canada's Toronto office for approx. 5 years
- Great cause
- Amazing opportunities to support field work
- Highly collaborative culture
- Strong international network
- Lots of flexibility in shaping roles to align with personal interests and strengths
- Some truly exceptional colleagues, close-knit and supportive team
cons:
- Poor leadership created a negative (even toxic) corporate culture that led to extremely high turnover rate and inability to work effectively
- Lack of focus on concrete conservation
- Many key internal and external relationships damaged by poor leadership, affecting funding and ability to make an impact
- Very limited opportunities for advancement
- Lots of fiefdoms within the organization, pulling it in different directions

pros: Some Great colleagues and opportunities to do amazing work. Wonderful efforts to do the right thing by everyone.
cons: Too much stress and bullying with too many restructures, and lack of compassion and respect.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Washington, DC
pros: We have off every other Friday and most management is really laid-back and flexible about time off.  I never feel like I have to worry about annual leave because I always have time. People are generally very nice and committed to saving the environment in their private lives as well so the culture is great.
cons: Not much in terms of upward mobility which has been a criticism of the company for some time, especially people starting out on the lower rungs. Pay isn't great, but maybe that's just for my position. No tuition help but it's still so competitive that you pretty much need a Master's to move up in any way, and that's still not a promise that you'll get a promotion.

review_title: Diversity and Inclusion and the Marketing/Membership team
job_title: Online Marketing Associate Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: Overall I think this is a general good, organized, thoughtful place to work at times
cons: I know that for black individuals (especially in the marketing/membership department) they have to work 2x as hard to get 1/2 the credit, acknowledgment,  and praise than other races in that space. It can be an incredibly difficult, stressful  and borderline abusive place to be as a Black person, especially depending on the manager you have. Be mindful of that before you decide to work in this environment.

review_title: Great Non-profit to work for, but has the same problems all non-profits have
pros: Awesome, laid-back atmosphere with smart and friendly co-workers. Great benefits and work schedule. Dedicated to the mission of saving the environment.
cons: Like all non-profits they struggle with how to justify spending money not on the core mission. Old ways and procedures are hard to change. The 'old guard' staff who may have been effective once, are not let go when their work quality degrades.

pros:
Great set of people,amazing work, a good peer group and superiors who guide you.
Food available inside the building and located in the heart of the city near the UN and other important places.
Flexible working hours.
Great exposure and an amazing brand name.
Amazing work culture and the best values I've ever seen.
cons:
Since it is a non profit,salary isn't high.
Office is not like a huge corporates but gives a very homely feel.
Food isnt great so got to eat out if you want a good meal.
Some of the computers are outdated.
No wifi access provided .

review_title: Friendly place to work but not every employee is treated fairly.
pros: It is a great place to work if you have a family. Most managers are very accommodating to employees who want a great work-life balance. The people are also very friendly and the senior management team is very approachable. There is a real sense that staff care about helping each other out.
cons: Like most non-profits, there are a lot of dinosaurs and politics. Internal equity among salaries and development opportunities is not well managed  and does not seem to exist (lack of transparency and fairness). For an organization that promotes sustainability, many staff seem to be flying all over the globe to attend meetings.

review_title: Strategic and visionary but terrible management
pros:
- Brand recognition to be working for one of the most effective global environmental orgs. (but WWF also knows this, so will leverage their brand to pay less to consultants and staff)
- Getting to work on global issues and traveling to those places around the world
- Working with truly dedicated and brilliant and strategic thought-leaders
cons:
- Utter lack of management competency. Their promotion/advancement model is based off of subject-matter mastery, so if you really know the field and the latest issues, you will advance ultimately to becoming a manager, even though you have no ability and no demonstration of any past experience to manage. Staff will suffer from professional stagnation for years under poor/lack of management. 
- Advancement is too dependent on managerial style. No standard advancement model for the organization, so you will see different advancement rates in different departments, regardless of similar breadths of responsibilities
- Poor understanding of DEI basics
- Toxic environment for people of color 
- Zero work-life balance. Don't be fooled by their "Panda Fridays", where you get every other Friday off. You essentially don't get paid for those Fridays, and are still expected to work and respond. Bi-weekly pay period is comprised of 70 hours. 
- They put on countless staff goodies, such as bringing in quarterly dessert trucks, omelette stations, and all the wondrous stuff that seem so magical. But keep in mind that staff below Mid-Level Management are severely underpaid. These distractions are just that: distractions, to make you feel that at least you get these fun activities, despite the low pay. 
- The US office conducted an office-wide survey to assess and potentially improve on their staff satisfaction levels. Their survey questions on DEI, in particular, were designed to draw out general perspectives of staff (i.e., "what does DEI mean to you? Is it important?), instead of actually asking "How is WWF performing in making this place as inclusive as it can be? Do you feel heard?"). The whole internal assessment/initiative was flawed and was really not designed well to actually help WWF improve on the areas it really needs help on. So the fact that the HR department spent significant time and energy and resources on this effort, which produced something so flawed in design from the outset is a huge red flag that the organization really doesn't understand how much it's not hearing its people. 
- HR is there to protect company assets, not you, the employee.

pros: Super dedicated staff, critical mission, the HQ building is amazing and the facilities staff is awesome.
cons: WWF is on it's way through a season of huge restructuring. Morale is low, and leadership is disconnected. Everyone is unsure whether the radical shifts that were made will work out, and the group of people who got laid off included several rock stars in the field of conservation.

pros: Great colleagues. Flexible work environment. Positive mission. You have the flexibility to learn a lot on the job and be creative.
cons: Restructuring is never painless or perfect, but the International change management team did not do the process efficiently or humanly. A lot of staff were made redundant and then asked to stay for years after being given a letter. Very political and people are promoted based on who likes who not on hard work or results (there is no real performance management system in place). The salary review process is also not transparent and seems to be all over the place.

review_title: Needs fresh thinking and new blood
pros: Exciting work done, huge brand image due to the excellent wildlife work done in the past, dedication and passion from the employees working for long  still exists
cons: Definitely needs a change in guard, new lot of employees only working for their salaries, less dedication and passion seen today, very bureaucratic style of functioning, very hierarchical

review_title: Smoke & Mirrors, though there is good!
pros: WWF has an amazing mission that is supported by a passionate energetic staff. The passion in which teams approach their work contribute to a great work environment. The recently introduced bonus system, like any new system, has it's flaws, but nonetheless it's great to have and boost morale. My direct supervisor is great and encourages growth, learning and welcomes ideas within our team. The benefits and flexible work schedules offered by WWF are pretty great. I think the environment is great for interns and people just starting on their career paths. The organization has the potential to be great both internally as well as externally!  They are in the cusp and simply need to breakthrough!
cons: Senior management does not appear to be on the same page; there is lots of mixed messages. Management does not seem to support free thinking while stating that they do. To be a non-profit, there seems to be loads of red tape in order to get anything done. The organization, though a conservation organization, does not seem to invest in internal sustainable initiatives. The organization does not seem to invest in the operations (support) side of the organization which contributes to lower morale. The organizations appears to fear change and growth moving into the 21st century; though some systems are slowing improving. The organization lacks internal resources - both human and technology - that assist staff in adequately performing duties. Promotions and salary increases seem to be linked directly to the years of service you have offered to the organization instead of experience and individual contributions made throughout the performance period.

review_title: Great place to gain experience but not to advance
pros: Very flexible work hours, amazing health benefits- better than the Federal Government. The salary is ok.
cons: To do well here you must be a self-starter. You can not wait for directions because you will not get it and they will blame you for job not completed. There is a huge management problem. Mangers do not know how to be mangers.  You have to be comfortable with managing up. Also very hard to get promoted.

pros:
Great mission
Great health and transit benefits 
Focused mission-driven employees
Excellent impact on the community
cons:
Very hierarchical and bureaucratic
Not-so-great work-life balance
Not as nimble as management would have you believe 
Very Poor internal communication
Room of advancement is slow and seems to be based on tenure within the organization not always merit
Poor salary structure
Management resistant to change and set in their ways

pros: The conservation work is top notch - science-based, practical, and exciting. Work-life balance is very good with summer hours and the offices are closed from Christmas Eve through New Years. Pay and benefits are great.
cons: Terrible senior management - very hierarchical and bureaucratic. Many empty promises. CEO is not engaged and is very moody. CCO ignores junior staff and is very negative. CFO jumps to negative conclusions and likes to undermine staff. Most meetings lack agendas and staff just spin their wheels at meetings.

pros:
Bullying and anxiety, poker faces every level. 
The management team care nothing about you as a person. They only think their salary and benefits.
No policies, no corporate environment.  CEO was not a professional, she does not have the capacity for conservation, she only markets herself and the company. 
Very bad management.
cons: I worked for conservation department for many years  I had friends and if you love the soul of the nature and do not care about the salary, management and the benefits you can  work but if you think for other management issues  I do not recommend. Think about your career! I'd like to mention that  my comments are related with only TURKEY- WWF Office.

review_title: good place to work, fun environment
pros: I was working as a door to door fundraiser on the behalf of WWF. Overall I was satisfied, the opportunities for training and progression were good and I the working environment was very friendly.
cons: I didn't like the working hours for that particular role, because I by the time I finished work most of the people still were not home and I wasted a lot of time visiting empty houses. Therefore the potential for earnings was limited which in the end was the reason why I left

pros: Incredible breadth of experience, great connections, excellent opportunities for learning through multiple brownbag talks throughout the week. Every other Friday is off. They give the long-term interns a lot of responsibility.
cons: Siloed (although there seem to be constant efforts to improve this), some staff are rude to interns or entry-level employees.

pros:
- Great colleagues
- Casual attire
- Everyone who works there does it because they care
- Friendly colleagues
- Good work/life balance
cons:
- Very low pay
- Overstretched staff
- Under-appreciated by senior staff members
- No accountability
- No career progression because always hiring from outside
- Lack of transparency

review_title: Guidelines for attendants are pretty ambiguous
pros: The course is informative. (Groups of environmental enthusiasts are selected to join their newly-launched scheme, who might become their permanent staff after qualifying for the exam.) Attendants are conscientious and supportive to each other.
cons: Guidelines for attendants are pretty ambiguous. Some well-performed candidates might also failed in the exam.

pros:
Really great organisation to work for. Particularly the people! Great spirit!
If you want to contribute to global change - this is the place to work.
cons: Sometimes the organisation is preoccupied with the internal strategy development. Athough in today's world, the ability to change and remaim flexible is ever more important - too much restructuring can be counterproductive.

review_title: Awesome! The best place I have ever worked.
pros: The people at the World Wildlife Fund are not only focused on saving the planet, but all of the departments work together to accomplish their goal.  They are friendly, knowledgable, an understanding of family.  They are also encouraging and supportive of your efforts.  The comany offers many opportunities to expand your knowledge!
cons: The only con is that you have to use the metro or find parking to get there.

review_title: Family-like atmosphere, perfect opportunity to meet people in the energy and climate change field
pros:
Family-like atmosphere, perfect opportunity to meet people in the energy and climate change field
Achieve some true personal values; work with people who don't only work for pay checks;
cons: kind of slow paste, not that efficient, sometimes work can  be repetitive; when doing basic level jobs sometimes not that fun; pay is limited given that it is Non-profit

pros:
Lovely office.
Incredible cause. 
Some great people (not all). Mix of high talent and those who have sat there for years.
cons:
Some old-timers with bad bullying behaviour who are allowed to get away with it / go under the radar whilst making their staff miserable.
Ineffective recruitment that puts off top talent
Too hierarchical and impossible decision making: takes forever for anything to get done.

review_title: Powerful mission, cool work, nice people but no strategy.
pros:

cons:

- Long term career development is not nurtured.

pros: The cause. Genuine team members who give their all.
cons: Useless Executive Team: poor management behaviours; lack of respect for employees

pros: good benefits, fun organization. you feel satisfied as you are working for a good cause to help the wildlife. you get to meet a lot of different people from a lot of different regions ranging from different ethnicities.
cons: the pay is good but might be a little south side from the private sector. you can always use ur experience in the private sector later if you wish too. you might have to travel frequently

pros:
- Involved in one of the most noble mandates: conserving mother earth and ensuring sustainability in both small and large scale developments so that we don't compromise the ability of future generations enjoying what we have now
- progressive management team
- Young work force and good mix with the older generation
cons:
- Affirmation culture is not strong in the organization
- work life balance is a myth
- benefits are not uniform across within grades

review_title: Was a Great organization to work for
job_title: Programmer Analyst Principal Leader in Bangkok
pros: The non profit with the most conservation funds to do work. Wonderful colleagues and the ability to work across national boundaries and various cultures.I was given a great deal of autonomy to implement the programme objectives.
cons: Too much time wasted in processes and meetings. Too much time wasted in crafting too many policies. Organization more worried about it's survival than worrying about the mission/vision our founders laid out. Offices with the money call the shots.

review_title: The British colonial legacy lives on at WWF Australia
pros: A great place to work if you're from the UK. That's about it.
cons: Anyone not from the UK need not apply. The staff and management are shamelessly chauvinistic toward anyone not British. It's a british-expat import business, basically. If they do hire you, you'll find your English mocked, you'll be passed over for promotions and you'll work on the least important projects. You'll be constantly reminded the you don't measure up on account your weren't born in the UK. Anti-semitism and homophobia are also common. And if you complain to their HR department. They will simply show you the door.

review_title: World Wildlife Fund is a great place to work.
pros: The work is meaningful.  The benefits are great.  Most of the people working there are really nice, too, and good at what they do.
cons: There is some bureaucracy and, as is common in the nonprofit world, decisions sometimes are made slowly and so there are cases of “hurry up and wait.”  Even with the drawbacks, however, World Wildlife Fund is one of the best organizations I’ve ever worked for.

pros:
- Helping the environment
- get to learn about different animals ( Depending on your project) 
- Great like minded people 
- Great experience moving forward
cons:
-it was very difficult to get a hold of the management
- most of the jobs were internally accessible, i had to work my way up through volunteering to qualify to any paid job

review_title: WWF Kenya has lots of muslim nepotism and is run like a shop
pros: WWF is an International Organisation with global reach
cons:
There is very high turn over. Members of staff work on egg shells. The director has a culture of hiring people from his muslim religion/somali culture at the expense of real qualified staff.

work place politics mess up work  and the real organisation.
Most people who leave will never talk good of the organisation. staff are constantly looking for employment because they are so insecure and dont know when their time is. The head of the organisation is so inhumane and has no human heart. Would care more for animals than humans.

pros: The best reasons tow work here is because they people are very friendly, and the company cares about work - life balance.
cons: Probably the downside to working here is that the pay is not so good because it is an NGO, and also the work can be sometimes boring.

job_title: Agriculture and Aquaculture Program Manager in San Pedro Sula
pros: Working towards getting sustainable production practices among agribusiness players in Mesoamerica was rewarding, including close collaboration with other NGOs, government Officials, agribussines enterprises, communities and small holders was amasing.
cons: After hard work implementing sustainable production practices and see amaizing results, watch companies to go back to old practices due to change in management or ownership.

review_title: This is a brand & comms organisation, not a conservation charity
pros: The pay is better than other conservation NGOs but beware that there's a running inside joke that they pay you more so that you put up with the cr*p that goes on there...
cons:
There is a deeply ingrained bullying culture within the organisation where HR and senior management seem to think it is OK to disempower, disrespect & manipulate its employees.  People have been bullied for years there and have had multiple meetings with HR but nothing is done about it.  This is sad.
The excessive amounts of meetings that go on and the fact that things take SO LONG to be signed off because everything has to be agreed by 20 thousand people and everyone has to have their say.  This is not a nimble organisation but rather more like a dying sloth.
Overly controlling line managers that actively stop you from excelling in your job due to their own insecurities.
Massive lack of any form of career progression.
New CEO and her cronies that have been nabbed from her old work place (Save the Children) without a proper hiring process. 
No person in the senior management team with any form of direct conservation experience.
New strategy seems to be a roadmap for world domination rather than to actually create positive conservation change.
The colonial nature of WWF-UK calling the shots on how developing nations should manage their wildlife.
The stifling work environment where there is no team spirit and everyone seems to be out to stab colleagues in the back rather than work collaboratively.
The huge amounts of supporters' money wasted on stupid things like croissants, t-shirts, lunches for senior management and expensive TV ads that have minimal conservation impact.
The fact that the office is in Woking, which is a dive of a commuter town in Surrey.


The massive lack of accountability within the HUGE comms team - just because you get coverage in a top newspaper does not necessarily mean you're helping to improve conservation. Where is the theory of change and the actual indicators measuring impact?
The building itself, whilst it looks nice from the outside and on the face of it, is actually more like working in a dingy multistory concrete carpark. The open plan is draining on everyone.

pros: Good work environment, everyone prioritizes a healthy work/life balance, co-workers are very intelligent and for the most part everyone cares deeply about the work we do.
cons: Unfortunately interns  who are doing important work and research that make the organization run are barely paid anything (or are unpaid!) while people higher up make excessively high salaries

review_title: Came for internship, stayed on for years.
pros: Very flexible, with options to work from home. The amenities are great: extensive kitchens, multiple conference rooms, etc. The dress code and general atmosphere is casual. My paid internship was $15/hour, which is very high for a non-profit internship.
cons: Since I was not a contracted employee, it was always up in the air whether my position would be extended. The decision makers regarding any situation may not work in the same office or even the same country.

pros: Great brand that inspires trust and connects emotionally with the public
cons: Poor management largely inefficient, lack of impact of conservation programs, disconnect between what the organization does (environmental advocacy) and what the public perceives the organization to be (wildlife protection).

pros: The WWF is a good organization filled with bright, dedicated, innovative people all working toward related, if not the same goals.  The people make this organization.
cons: Sometimes it is difficult to get things done - to get people to agree or endorse one path. There is a lot to do and too little time.

pros: The goals of the organizations are great. The network and the image helps you make impact and develop some skills.
cons: Unskilled senior management. Lack of vision. Exploiation of young enthousiast environmentalists which are demotivated to work longer in WWF by low investments in personal development, low payment and sometimes authoritarian management.

job_title: Program Coordinator in Brasília, Federal District
pros: International experience, opportunities to work with people from different places and cultures. A few very good professionals that make the good image of the NGO.
cons: Politics are by far more important than performance and technical knowledge, as a consequence there is a weak leadership without strategic vision. Staff are territorial on relationships with project partners, stakeholders, organizations, private sector, gov etc- challenging to collaborate internally. It's an NGO but most people are more interested in their own gains than in nature conservation.

pros: Panda Friday's! Incredible benefits. Wonderful people. Not a ton of office politics. Overall a great place to work!
cons: Not much, but some office politics, primarily dealing with ownership of projects. There are a lot of cooks in the kitchen sometimes, and other times too much division between teams. I've worked in many places, so this is nothing new, and it is a relatively small issue compared to unhealthy company cultures

pros: Dedicated, experienced and intelligent workforce and friendly culture. Support of  recognized and respected brand, and representation in media and politics. Beautiful eco office, supportive of flexible hours. Lots of important and exciting work going on!
cons: WWF is a charity and as expected, salaries are not comparable with private sector

pros: The organization is very people friendly. It offers very good work-life balance options. It has many talented and nice people. Overall, I feel very happy everyday working there.
cons: A little bit old-fashioned in the IT and communication aspect. I have only worked here for half a year. So far have not experienced much down sides .

review_title: Amazing organisation with extremely talented and dedicated staff all working for a worthy cause
pros: The people, the cause, the opportunities and development
cons: Some challenging senior management who lack agreement and prolong decision making. There are small pockets of bullying which despite being raised to HR and senior management have never been addressed.

pros: Every Other Friday off. Good vacation and benefits
cons: VERY clique oriented.  Managers have poor management skills and projects take forever to develop.  Operates like a government job where the priority is to do what they have always done. There are two groups there, those that have been there forever and those that stay for a year or two and leave.

pros: It was a privilege to work with top scientists and highly experienced policymakers on some of the most immediate issues facing the developing world -- many that you might not associate with endangered species. Flexible schedule, very kind and dedicated and unique people.
cons: Not huge salaries; at times hard and isolating to be remote or re-located.

review_title: A good place to help the environment.
pros: Supervisors are very supportive, everyone is pretty laid back, casual dress code for most employees.  The HQ is LEED platinum, so the company is environmentally friendly from the ground up.
cons: LOTS of vegetarians.  This is not the place to go to discuss the awesome time you had at Ultimate BBQ Festival 2011.  And the lower cubicles, while letting in lots of light, lead to lots of awkward eye contact.

pros: There are many benefits to working at WWF including, but not limited to: brilliant people, a great work-life balance, travel opportunities, a noble mission, Panda Friday (every other Friday off), awesome retirement plan and being part of a  well-respected brand.
cons: Too many meetings and sometimes-arbitrary hierarchy..and while there is a push toward a culture of innovation, the organization as a whole is not there..yet.
